PROCEDURE: Ultrasound-guided therapeutic thoracentesis, left
INDICATION: 66-year-old male with new moderate left pleural effusion and dyspnea; suspected parapneumonic effusion.

ANESTHESIA:
Local anesthesia with lidocaine; no systemic sedation (patient cooperative).

PROCEDURE DESCRIPTION:
Point-of-care ultrasound demonstrated a moderate free-flowing anechoic effusion on the left without septations. Under sterile conditions, the left posterior axillary line was marked. After local infiltration, a thoracentesis catheter was advanced into the pleural space with ultrasound guidance.

A total of 1.2 L of clear yellow fluid was removed and sent for cell count, Gram stain and culture, pH, LDH, protein, and cytology. The catheter was then removed and a dressing applied.

COMPLICATIONS:
None. No cough, chest pain, or air aspiration. Post-procedure chest radiograph showed interval decrease in effusion without pneumothorax.

PLAN:
Resume antibiotics. Review pleural fluid studies to differentiate transudate vs exudate. Outpatient pulmonary follow-up in 1â€“2 weeks.
